page.title: 12Keeping Thurlow beautiful
page.content: Pollution presents no problem here, even the black smuts caused by stubble burning are kept to the minimum by the landowner's policy of ploughing in, despite the extra time and expense involved. Ditches and hedgerows are protected, wild flowers being allowed to bloom and seed before the verges are cut or sprayed, indeed the owner personally keeps and eye on particularly rare plants. A walk along the narrow winding lanes reveals the rewards of this husbandry; daredevil pheasants dart across the road, a shy rabbit hops into a wheat field, butterflies hover among the tansy and hedgeroses, and spring reveals cowslips, oxslips and the occasional bold hare surveying the empty landscape. Roadside avenues of trees have been planted, & the Anglian Water Authority breeds coarse fish here.
